Hello, World!

As usual in programming language dissertations, we start with a simple program that displays a Hello, World! message to show the most simple end-to-end process.

The process is simple and the same in every language:

  1. Write the code file (in the specific) languages
  2. Compile the code into an executable
  3. Run the resulting executable

Here it goes...

  1. Write the code

    In the IDE, create the code file:

    • ILAsm

      hello.il

    • C#

      hello.cs

    • F#

      hello.fs

    • VB.Net

      hello.vb

  2. Compile

    To compile the code, open the "Developer Command Prompt" for the version of Visual Studio installed and run the following command:

    • ILAsm

      ilasm hello.il

    • C#

      csc hello.cs

    • F#

      fsc hello.fs

    • VB.Net

      vbc hello.vb

  3. Run the program

    In all of the languages, the previous compliation step resulted in a hello.exe file. to run program, simply invoke that executable in the command prompt (the Developer Command Prompt used to compile will suffice)

    hello.exe

    That should have the output:

    Hello, World!

All the code produced in this series lives in this GitHub repository.
